title: The effects of underwater pressure on the body - Neosha S Kashef

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the bodily damage caused by rapid changes in pressure that a fish may experience when reeled up to the surface?

options.label: C
options.text: The volume remains constant regardless of pressure

options.label: B
options.text: The amount increases as partial pressure increases

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: By holding it underwater until it recovers

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of recompression for a fish that has experienced barotrauma?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Its stomach projects out of its mouth

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: What did democracy really mean in Athens? - Melissa Schwartzberg

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Athens, how were most legislative positions typically filled?

options.text: Through direct elections by all citizens

options.label: B
options.text: By appointment from a council of elders

options.label: C
options.text: By random lottery from a pool of citizen volunteers

options.label: A
options.text: Generals, magistrates, and members of the Boule

multiple-choice.question: What principle guided the Athenian system of direct democracy, allowing any eligible citizen to participate in governance?
In the Athenian system, which groups of people were excluded from full citizenship?

options.label: C
options.text: That it was anarchic and run by fools

options.label: B
options.text: The restriction of powers to elites

options.label: C
options.text: The duty of all citizens to participate in governance

options.label: D
options.text: The concentration of power in a few individuals

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how does the democratic principle behind sortition still survive today?

options.label: A
options.text: Through election by lottery in modern democracies

options.label: B
options.text: Through citizens' assemblies and deliberative polls only

options.label: C
options.text: Through the use of sortition in modern elections

options.label: D
options.text: Through jury selection, citizens' assemblies, and deliberative polls

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the Earth's surface is covered by water?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

title: Platoâ€™s Allegory of the Cave - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: Who is the author of the Allegory of the Cave, a philosophical passage found in Book VII of "The Republic"?
What is the primary purpose of the Allegory of the Cave in the context of Plato's philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: To describe the ideal society and promote rule by philosopher kings exclusively

options.label: B
options.text: To examine the concept of justice in isolation

options.label: C
options.text: To illustrate the challenges of educating the public and explore the nature of reality and knowledge

options.label: D
options.text: To critique Athenian democracy without offering an alternative

multiple-choice.question: What does the Allegory of the Cave convey about human perception and understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: People naturally seek truth and knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: People often prefer to remain in ignorance and may resist new knowledge

options.label: C
options.text: Human perception is always accurate and reliable

options.label: D
options.text: The masses are always receptive to new ideas and perspectives

multiple-choice.question: According to Plato's theory of forms, what is the relationship between the physical world and ideal forms?

options.label: A
options.text: The physical world is the ultimate reality

options.label: B
options.text: The physical world perfectly reflects ideal forms

options.label: C
options.text: The physical world is a flawed reflection of ideal forms, such as roundness or beauty

options.label: D
options.text: The physical world has no connection to ideal forms

multiple-choice.question: In the context of the Allegory of the Cave, what is the problem of representation?

options.label: A
options.text: The difficulty of understanding the ideal forms

options.label: C
options.text: The problem of grouping concrete things under abstract terms

options.label: D
options.text: The issue of free will and moral responsibility

multiple-choice.question: How do the other prisoners react to the freed prisoner's return to the cave in the Allegory of the Cave?

options.label: A
options.text: They welcome him back as a hero and a source of knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: They are met with indifference and apathy

options.label: C
options.text: They are hostile and violent towards him, thinking he has been made stupid and blind

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to see him due to the darkness and their limited perception

multiple-choice.question: What does the Allegory of the Cave suggest about the masses in relation to knowledge and understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: The masses naturally seek truth and knowledge

options.label: B
options.text: The masses often resist new knowledge and may prefer to remain in ignorance

options.label: C
options.text: The masses are the ultimate authority and source of wisdom

options.label: D
options.text: The masses are irrelevant to the Allegory of the Cave and its themes

multiple-choice.question: What is the broader significance of the Allegory of the Cave in the context of Plato's philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a critique of Athenian democracy and the social order

options.label: B
options.text: It is a description of the ideal society and the role of philosopher kings

options.label: C
options.text: It is a discussion of the theory of forms and their relationship to reality

options.label: D
options.text: It is a metaphor for the nature of reality, knowledge, and the challenges of educating the public

multiple-choice.question: What does the prisoner's struggle towards the light in the Allegory of the Cave represent?

options.label: A
options.text: The struggle for power and social status

options.label: B
options.text: The struggle for comfort and familiarity

options.label: C
options.text: The struggle for physical freedom and liberation

options.label: D
options.text: The struggle for knowledge, understanding, and enlightenment

multiple-choice.question: What fundamental question does the Allegory of the Cave pose about human knowledge and perception?

options.label: A
options.text: Can we be certain of our surroundings and the physical world?

options.label: B
options.text: Is the ideal society possible and achievable?

options.label: C
options.text: Can we be confident in what we think we know, or are we just perceiving shadows of reality?

options.label: D
options.text: Is the theory of forms true and universally applicable?

title: Why itâ€™s so hard to cure HIV/AIDS - Janet Iwasa

multiple-choice.question: In what year was a man cured of HIV, marking the first and, so far, only documented case of HIV being cured?

options.label: A
options.text: Through casual contact with an infected person

options.label: B
options.text: Through exchanges of bodily fluids, such as unprotected sex and contaminated needles

options.label: C
options.text: Through direct contact with an infected person's skin

multiple-choice.question: Which type of immune cells are specifically targeted and infected by HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: The initial stage of HIV infection

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of antiretroviral therapy in managing HIV?

options.label: B
options.text: To manage levels of HIV and prevent T cell counts from getting low enough for the disease to progress to AIDS

multiple-choice.question: What is a crucial requirement for HIV-positive patients undergoing antiretroviral therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: They must take their drugs for a limited period

options.label: B
options.text: They can stop taking their drugs after a certain period

options.label: C
options.text: They must take their drugs for the rest of their lives

options.label: D
options.text: They can adjust their dosage as needed without consulting a doctor

multiple-choice.question: Why is it challenging to cure HIV with current treatments?

options.label: A
options.text: Because HIV is a highly contagious virus

options.label: B
options.text: Because HIV is resistant to current drugs

options.label: C
options.text: Because HIV integrates its genetic material into the DNA of healthy T cells, making it difficult to eradicate

multiple-choice.question: What is one research approach being explored to develop a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a vaccine to prevent HIV transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Using gene editing to remove HIV DNA from infected cells

options.label: C
options.text: Using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information

options.label: D
options.text: Using antiretroviral therapy to manage levels of HIV

multiple-choice.question: What are some research approaches being explored to develop a true cure for HIV?

options.label: A
options.text: Using a vaccine to prevent HIV transmission

options.label: B
options.text: Using gene editing to remove HIV DNA from infected cells and/or using a drug to activate all cells harboring the HIV genetic information

options.label: C
options.text: Using antiretroviral therapy to manage levels of HIV

options.label: D
options.text: Using immunotherapy to boost the immune system

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what proportion of HIV-positive patients in Sub-Saharan Africa had access to antiretrovirals in 2012?

title: How does the thyroid manage your metabolism? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the thyroid gland in the body?

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones that regulate metabolism and energy use in cells

options.label: C
options.text: To filter waste and toxins from the blood

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate body growth and development

multiple-choice.question: Which two hormones are produced by the thyroid gland to regulate metabolism and energy use in cells?
What is the role of the pituitary gland in relation to the thyroid gland?

options.label: A
options.text: To produce hormones that stimulate the thyroid gland

options.label: B
options.text: To produce hormones that inhibit the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: To sense hormone levels in the blood and send instructions to the thyroid gland

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the thyroid gland producing excessive hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypothyroidism, characterized by a slower metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperthyroidism, characterized by a slower metabolism

options.label: C
options.text: Hyperthyroidism, characterized by a faster metabolism and increased energy use

multiple-choice.question: What are some common symptoms of hyperthyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight gain, sluggishness, and sensitivity to cold

options.label: B
options.text: Rapid weight loss, constant hunger, difficulty sleeping, and a faster heartbeat

options.label: C
options.text: Fatigue, muscle weakness, and hair loss

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the thyroid gland producing insufficient hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: Hyperthyroidism, characterized by a faster metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: Hypothyroidism, characterized by a slower metabolism and decreased energy use

multiple-choice.question: What are some common symptoms of hypothyroidism?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and difficulty sleeping

options.label: B
options.text: Weight gain, sluggishness, sensitivity to cold, and swollen joints

options.label: C
options.text: Fatigue, muscle weakness, and hair loss

multiple-choice.question: What can cause the thyroid gland to malfunction and lead to hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism?

options.label: C
options.text: Chemical imbalances in the body, certain diseases, or growths in the thyroid

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of medical treatment in managing thyroid problems?

options.label: A
options.text: To stimulate the thyroid gland to produce more hormones

options.label: B
options.text: To inhibit the thyroid gland from producing hormones

options.label: C
options.text: To trigger the thyroid gland's activities and bring the body back to a steady metabolic rate

options.label: D
options.text: To replace hormones produced by the thyroid gland

multiple-choice.question: Why is the thyroid gland important for maintaining a healthy body?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces hormones that regulate metabolism and energy use in cells

options.label: B
options.text: It filters waste and toxins from the blood

options.label: C
options.text: It stores nutrients and releases hormones produced by the thyroid gland

options.label: C
options.text: Matter and energy can neither be created nor destroyed.

options.label: D
options.text: It regulates blood sugar levels through digestive enzymes

title: How one piece of legislation divided a nation - Ben Labaree, Jr.

multiple-choice.question: What 1854 event is often credited with the collapse of the Second Party System in the United States?

options.label: A
options.text: The founding of the Republican Party

options.label: B
options.text: The passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Act

multiple-choice.question: Which compromise allowed slavery in Missouri while prohibiting it in the remaining Louisiana Territory?
Who was the Democratic Senator from Illinois who promoted a transcontinental railroad across the Northern Plains?
What was the primary purpose of the Kansas-Nebraska Act, according to Stephen A. Douglas?

options.label: B
options.text: To organize the Kansas and Nebraska territories and allow residents to decide on slavery

options.label: D
options.text: To promote western expansion and the construction of a transcontinental railroad

multiple-choice.question: Which party was founded in 1854 by anti-slavery elements from both the Whig and Democratic parties?
What was the outcome of the 1856 Pottawatomie Massacre?

options.label: B
options.text: The killing of five pro-slavery farmers by John Brown and his sons

options.label: C
options.text: The end of Bleeding Kansas violence

options.label: D
options.text: The abolition of slavery in Kansas

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first Republican presidential candidate in 1856?
Who won the 1860 presidential election?
What was the primary consequence of the Kansas-Nebraska Act on the nation?

options.label: A
options.text: It united the nation behind a single party

options.label: B
options.text: It strengthened the Second Party System

options.label: C
options.text: It led to the immediate abolition of slavery

options.label: D
options.text: It divided the nation along sectional lines, increased tensions, and ultimately contributed to the outbreak of the Civil War

multiple-choice.question: Why is the Kansas-Nebraska Act considered one of the most consequential pieces of legislation in American history?

options.label: B
options.text: It united the nation behind a single party

options.label: C
options.text: It had a limited impact on the nation

options.label: D
options.text: It divided the nation, increased the likelihood of the Civil War, and ultimately led to the collapse of the Second Party System

title: The sonic boom problem - Katerina Kaouri

multiple-choice.question: Who was the first person to break the sound barrier and travel faster than the speed of sound in 1947?
What was the name of the aircraft that Chuck Yeager flew to break the sound barrier in 1947?
At sea level, approximately what is the speed of sound?
What phenomenon occurs when the frequency of sound waves changes due to the motion of the source, causing approaching objects to sound higher pitched?
What is the shape of the pressure signature that represents the variation of pressure in the air due to a supersonic aircraft, characterized by two sudden changes in pressure?
When the Mach cone meets the ground, what shape is formed, helping to determine the area affected by a sonic boom?
What set of equations is used to find the variation of pressure in the air due to a supersonic aircraft flying through it?
What is the primary effect of a sonic boom on the ground?

options.label: A
options.text: It creates a shock wave with a thunder-like noise that can cause distress to people and animals or even damage buildings

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a sudden change in temperature

multiple-choice.question: Which prehistoric animal may have been capable of producing a sonic boom by cracking its tail faster than sound, possibly to deter predators?
What is the term for the trail left by the Mach cone as it travels forward, which helps determine the area affected by a sonic boom?

title: How do your kidneys work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the kidneys in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature and produce hormones exclusively

options.label: B
options.text: To dispose of waste products and turn them into urine

options.label: C
options.text: To filter blood and regulate blood pressure exclusively

options.label: D
options.text: To digest food and absorb nutrients

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many liters of blood do the kidneys filter every 24 hours?
What is the function of the glomerulus in the nephron?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect waste products in the blood

options.label: B
options.text: To filter the blood and allow certain ingredients to pass through

options.label: C
options.text: To reabsorb nutrients back into the blood directly

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the ingredients detected by the tubules in the nephron that are needed by the body?

options.label: B
options.text: They are reabsorbed back into the blood in the amounts needed

options.label: C
options.text: They are stored in the kidneys

options.label: D
options.text: They are broken down and reused for other purposes

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the ureters in the urinary system?

options.label: A
options.text: To filter the blood and produce urine

options.label: B
options.text: To transport urine from the kidneys to the bladder

multiple-choice.question: Why does urine appear yellower when you're less hydrated?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the presence of excess water

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the presence of waste products

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the lack of water in the blood, resulting in more concentrated urine

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the presence of excess minerals

multiple-choice.question: Which hormone is produced by the kidneys to increase blood pressure?
What is the role of the kidneys in regulating the body's fluid levels?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase fluid levels in the body

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease fluid levels in the body

options.label: C
options.text: To stabilize fluid levels in the body

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the kidneys were not present in the body?

options.label: B
options.text: The body would experience minor difficulties

options.label: C
options.text: The body's bodily fluids would spiral out of control, leading to a buildup of waste and eventual death

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many nephrons are present in each kidney?

title: Why Shakespeare loved iambic pentameter - David T. Freeman and Gregory Taylor

multiple-choice.question: What key element in Shakespeare's language contributes to its unique sound and rhythm?

options.label: B
options.text: His use of stress on certain syllables

multiple-choice.question: In poetry, what is a "foot"?

options.label: A
options.text: A certain number of stressed and unstressed syllables forming a distinct unit

multiple-choice.question: What is a "dactyl" in poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: A metrical foot of three syllables with the first stressed and the second and third unstressed

options.label: B
options.text: A metrical foot of three syllables with the first unstressed and the second and third stressed

multiple-choice.question: What effect do the trochees have in the witches' chant in "Macbeth"?

options.label: A
options.text: They lend a lively and carefree tone

options.label: B
options.text: They lend an ominous and spooky tone

options.label: C
options.text: They lend a romantic and sentimental tone

options.label: D
options.text: They lend a heroic and triumphant tone

multiple-choice.question: What is "iambic pentameter" in poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of poetic meter where each line of verse is made up of five two-syllable iambs

options.label: B
options.text: A type of poetic meter where each line of verse is made up of three two-syllable iambs

options.label: C
options.text: A type of poetic meter where each line of verse is made up of two three-syllable iambs

options.label: D
options.text: A type of poetic meter where each line of verse is made up of four two-syllable iambs

multiple-choice.question: Why is iambic pentameter considered easy for actors to memorize and for the audience to understand?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is naturally suited to the English language

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a complex and difficult poetic meter

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a rare and unique poetic meter

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is commonly used in everyday speech

multiple-choice.question: What effect does Shakespeare's use of iambic pentameter have on his most poetic lines?

options.label: A
options.text: It adds a sense of tension and anxiety

options.label: B
options.text: It adds a sense of calm and serenity

options.label: C
options.text: It adds a sense of passion and emotion, mirroring the rhythm of the heart

options.label: D
options.text: It adds a sense of logic and reason

multiple-choice.question: Why do Shakespeare's characters often switch to iambic pentameter when speaking about their emotions and their place in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it is a way to express complex ideas

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is a way to add a sense of rhythm and music to poetry

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is a poetic meter that is naturally suited to the English language

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is a way to express deep emotions and introspection

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the word "iamb" being pronounced like the phrase "I am"?

options.label: B
options.text: It is a way to remember the meaning of iambic pentameter

options.label: C
options.text: It is a way to express deep emotions and introspection

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way to add a sense of rhythm and music to poetry

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the pirate walking in iambs?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a way to express deep emotions and introspection

options.label: B
options.text: It is a way to add a sense of rhythm and music to poetry

options.label: C
options.text: It is a way to remember the meaning of iambic pentameter

options.label: D
options.text: It is a living reminder of Shakespeare's favorite meter

title: Why do buildings fall in earthquakes? - Vicki V. May

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why buildings collapse during an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The earthquake itself causes the building to collapse directly.

options.label: B
options.text: The ground beneath the building splits apart, causing the building to collapse.

options.label: C
options.text: The displacement of the foundation and lower levels sends shock waves through the rest of the structure, causing it to vibrate and potentially collapse.

options.label: D
options.text: The building's foundation is not deep enough to withstand the earthquake.

multiple-choice.question: What two factors primarily determine a building's response to an earthquake?

options.label: A
options.text: The building's material type and shape of its columns

options.label: C
options.text: The earthquake's frequency and soil type

options.label: D
options.text: The building's height and foundation depth

multiple-choice.question: What phenomenon occurs when the frequency of an earthquake's seismic waves matches the natural frequency of a building?
How does increasing a building's mass affect its natural frequency?

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the natural frequency.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the natural frequency directly proportional to the mass.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of base isolation in earthquake-resistant design?

options.label: D
options.text: To isolate the foundation's displacement from the rest of the building

multiple-choice.question: How do low frequencies of motion differ from high frequencies of motion in terms of their impact on buildings?

options.label: A
options.text: Low frequencies cause more damage to shorter and stiffer buildings, while high frequencies cause more damage to taller and more flexible buildings.

options.label: B
options.text: Low frequencies cause more damage to buildings with high mass, while high frequencies cause more damage to buildings with low mass.

options.label: C
options.text: Low frequencies cause more damage to buildings with stiff structures, while high frequencies cause more damage to buildings with flexible structures.

options.label: D
options.text: Low frequencies cause more damage to taller and more flexible buildings, while high frequencies cause more damage to shorter and stiffer buildings.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of tuned mass damper systems in earthquake-resistant design?

options.label: D
options.text: To cancel out resonance by oscillating out of phase with the natural frequency

multiple-choice.question: What two factors primarily determine a building's natural frequency?

options.label: A
options.text: The building's material type and shape of its columns

options.label: B
options.text: The earthquake's frequency and soil type

options.label: C
options.text: The building's height and foundation depth

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of resonance in a building during an earthquake?

options.label: D
options.text: The building's vibration is amplified, potentially leading to collapse.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to designing earthquake-resistant buildings?

options.label: D
options.text: Building the smartest buildings that can adapt to seismic activity

title: Why the Arctic is climate change's canary in the coal mine - William Chapman

multiple-choice.question: What is the Arctic often referred to as in the context of predicting the impact of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: The weather station of the world

options.label: B
options.text: The canary in the coal mine

options.label: D
options.text: The climate model of the future

multiple-choice.question: Which type of surfaces are very effective at reflecting the sun's energy back into space?

options.label: B
options.text: White surfaces, like snow and ice

options.label: C
options.text: Green surfaces, like trees and grass

options.label: D
options.text: Brown surfaces, like soil and rocks

multiple-choice.question: What happens when the Arctic warms, causing some of the snow and ice to melt?

options.label: A
options.text: The ground and ocean underneath absorb less incoming sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: The increased heat absorbed by these surfaces causes even more melting

options.label: C
options.text: The temperature in the Arctic decreases

multiple-choice.question: How does Arctic sea ice contribute to a feedback mechanism through insulation?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the amount of heat transferred from the ocean to the atmosphere

options.label: B
options.text: By reducing the amount of sunlight being absorbed by the ocean

options.label: C
options.text: By forming a layer on the ocean's surface, acting as a buffer between the frigid arctic air and the relatively warmer water underneath

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing the amount of moisture in the atmosphere

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop occurs when the initial change leads to effects that work in the opposite direction?
What is the immediate effect of melting ice releasing moisture into the atmosphere during the Arctic summer?

options.label: A
options.text: The atmosphere warms by trapping the Earth's heat

options.label: B
options.text: The amount and thickness of clouds present decrease

options.label: C
options.text: The temperature in the Arctic decreases

options.label: D
options.text: The atmosphere cools by blocking more sunlight

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of the recently increased impact of positive feedbacks on the planet?

options.label: A
options.text: The North Pole warms at a slower rate than the equator

options.label: B
options.text: The reduced temperature differences between the North Pole and the equator may lead to slower jet stream winds

options.label: D
options.text: The weather patterns become less extreme

multiple-choice.question: What phrase do climate scientists use to describe the potential far-reaching impact of the Arctic on the rest of the planet?

options.label: C
options.text: What happens in the Arctic doesn't always stay in the Arctic

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the increased moisture and clouds in the atmosphere during most of the year (outside of the Arctic summer)?

options.label: A
options.text: The atmosphere cools by blocking more sunlight

options.label: B
options.text: The atmosphere warms by trapping the Earth's heat

options.label: C
options.text: The amount and thickness of clouds present decrease

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature in the Arctic decreases

multiple-choice.question: What type of feedback loop encourages stability by pushing a system towards equilibrium?

title: The great conspiracy against Julius Caesar - Kathryn Tempest

multiple-choice.question: Which Roman Senator claimed descent from Lucius Junius Brutus, who helped overthrow the tyrannical king Tarquin the Proud?

options.label: A
options.text: The concentration of power in one person

options.label: B
options.text: The absolute control of the people

options.label: D
options.text: That no one man should hold too much power

options.label: C
options.text: The establishment of a new government

options.label: B
options.text: Was only debated by ancient historians

options.text: Was only debated by modern historians

title: How do the lungs work? - Emma Bryce

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the respiratory system?

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells and clear the system of carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: To facilitate the digestion of food

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate waste from the body

multiple-choice.question: Which system controls the body's vital functions, including breathing, without conscious thought?
What are the small tubes that branch off from the bronchi and divide into thousands of smaller passages called?
What is the process by which oxygen and carbon dioxide are exchanged in the lungs?
What are the tiny air sacs at the end of each bronchiole where gas exchange occurs called?
What is the role of hemoglobin in the process of gas exchange in the lungs?

options.label: A
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells and unload carbon dioxide into the lungs

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate the body's pH levels

options.label: C
options.text: To facilitate the digestion of food

options.label: D
options.text: To eliminate waste from the body

multiple-choice.question: Which muscle flattens when the body prepares to take in oxygen-rich air?

options.label: B
options.text: To transport oxygen to the body's cells

options.label: C
options.text: To trigger the respiratory system to start functioning

multiple-choice.question: How many liters of air do the lungs inhale and exhale each day?
